hints_html:
Try a substitution.

Maybe it helps to rewrite the integrand as

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{e^{1/x}}{x^2} = x^{-2} e^{x^{-1}}.\end{aligned}\]
hints_raw:

question: 3 (a)
sols_html:
We follow the hints and first rewrite the integral.

\[\begin{aligned} \int_1^2 \frac{e^{1/x}}{x^2}\,dx = \int_1^2 x^{-2}e^{x^{-1}}\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

Now we substitute

\[\begin{aligned} u = x^{-1}, \quad \frac{du}{dx} = -x^{-2}, \quad dx = -x^2\,du.\end{aligned}\]

Further, for \(x=1\) we have \(u=1\), and for \(x=2\) we have \(u=1/2\). Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} \int_1^2 x^{-2}e^{x^{-1}}\,dx &= \int_1^{1/2} x^{-2}e^u(-x^2\,du) \\ &= -\int_1^{1/2} e^u\,du \\ &= \int_{1/2}^1 e^u\,du \\ &= \left.e^{u}\right|_{1/2}^1 \\ &= e-e^{1/2}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
We follow the hints and first rewrite the integral.
:<math> \int_1^2 \frac{e^{1/x}}{x^2}\,dx = \int_1^2 x^{-2}e^{x^{-1}}\,dx.</math>
Now we substitute
:<math> u = x^{-1}, \quad \frac{du}{dx} = -x^{-2}, \quad dx = -x^2\,du.</math>
Further, for <math>x=1</math> we have <math>u=1</math>, and for <math>x=2</math> we have <math>u=1/2</math>. Therefore,

<math>\begin{align}
\int_1^2 x^{-2}e^{x^{-1}}\,dx &= \int_1^{1/2} x^{-2}e^u(-x^2\,du) \\
&= -\int_1^{1/2} e^u\,du \\
&= \int_{1/2}^1 e^u\,du \\
&= \left.e^{u}\right|_{1/2}^1 \\
&= e-e^{1/2}.
\end{align}
</math>
